questions.text: A mother is concerned that her 1-year-old daughter has been having repeated episodes of UTI since birth. The pediatrician ordered a voiding cystourethrogram, which revealed reflux of urine into the upper collecting systems without any dilation. Under which grade of vesicoureteral reflux will this presentation be classified?
questions.solution:
Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) severity is graded according to the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V):

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I- VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II- VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III- VUR into the dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices.
  • Grade IV- VUR into a grossly dilated ureter
  • Grade V- Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man from eastern India was referred with a history of two weeks of fever which did not respond well to antibiotics. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy and abdominal distension with splenomegaly. A rapid antibody test with rk39 was found to be positive. A tissue smear from a splenic biopsy showed amastigotes. Which of the following is an oral drug that can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Miltefosine is the first oral drug against Leishmaniasis and it is registered for use in India.

Miltefosine is administered at a daily oral dose of 2.5mg/kg in two divided doses for 28 days. The side effects are short-lived and include nausea, vomiting, increased transaminases, and abnormal renal function.

This patient's clinical presentation of persistent fever, lymphadenopathy, and abdominal distension with splenomegaly along with the demonstration of amastigotes in tissue culture is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. A rapid immunochromatographic test to detect antibodies against rK39 recombinant antigen of L.infantum can be used on the field.

Medical therapy for leishmaniasis includes:

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate) - route IV or IM
  • If the initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used - route IV

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice - route IV infusion
  • Paromomycin (route IM) is as effective as amphotericin

Miltefosine is also the drug of choice for the treatment of post-kala azar dermal leishmaniasis.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of dermatomyositis?
  1. Asymmetric muscle weakness
  2. Heliotrope rash
  3. Proximal muscle weakness > Distal muscle weakness
  4. Males affected more than females
  5. Poor response to immunotherapies
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 3 are correct with respect to dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations. It affects females more than males and has no familial association. It is generally associated with an underlying malignancy

In dermatomyositis, skeletal muscle weakness involves proximal muscles symmetrically and on biopsy shows peri-fascicular atrophy.

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Gottron’s sign- flat erythematous rash that occurs symmetrically over the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and interphalangeal (IP) joints, elbows, knees, and ankles.
  • Gottron's papules - raised erythematous rash over the knuckles
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema
  • Shawl sign which is macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • Nail fold changes
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

Dermatomyositis is generally responsive to immunotherapy. The general prognosis is good in patients without underlying malignancy. Poor prognostic factors include advanced age, associated interstitial lung disease/cardiac involvement and late onset of treatment.

Asymmetric muscle weakness with familial involvement is seen in inclusion body myositis. It is more common in males than females. There is early involvement of distal muscles like flexors of the fingers, wrists, and extensors of the knees. The response is generally poor to immunotherapies.

The image below shows heliotrope rash.

The image below shows shawl sign. 

Gottron's papules

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis
Age of onset Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years  
Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No
Muscle involvement

Symmetric

Symmetric

Asymmetric
Histopathological Findings

Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates 

Perivascular infiltrates  

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles   
Association with connective tissue disease Scleroderma and mixed connective tissue only Yes Yes
Association with other autoimmune diseases Infrequent Frequent  Infrequent
Association with malignancy Yes (breast, ovarian, lung) and ILD  Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis)  No
Immunotherapy  Responsive  Responsive  Resistant

questions.text:
Match the following -

A - Calcium oxalate
B - Struvite
C - Cystine
D - Uric acid
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are -

1 - C. Cystine

2 - B. Struvite

3 - A. Calcium oxalate

4 - D. Uric acid

Cystine -Patients with cystinuria (an autosomal recessive disorder) are at risk for developing cystine stones.

Struvite stones -  Urease-producing organisms such as Proteus or Klebsiella causing chronic upper urinary tract infection are at higher risk for struvite stones. the are magnesium-ammonium phosphate stones. 

Calcium stones - Seen in conditions causing high urine calcium such as primary hyperparathyroidism and chronic acidemia from distal renal tubular acidosis. Also seen in the condition of high urine oxalate which is seen during a low-calcium diet and in malabsorption syndromes(small bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease), including a jejunoileal bypass for obesity (bariatric surgery), surgical bowel resection or diversion, or cystic fibrosis).

Uric Acid stones - Gout and Diabetes Mellitus are associated with uric acid stones.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text:
The below statements describe the steps occurring during the skeletal muscle contraction. What is the correct sequence of these events?
  1. Binding of calcium to the troponin and tropomyosin complex
  2. Detachment of head from actin
  3. Release of active sites in actin and binding of myosin with actin
  4. Release of ADP and phosphate from the myosin head
  5. Cleaving of ATP to ADP and phosphate by myosin head
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of contraction is 5, 1, 3, 4, 2.

Chemical Events during Muscle Contraction

  • Before contraction begins, the heads of the cross-bridges bind with ATP. The myosin head has ATPase activity which cleaves ATP to form ADP and phosphate. These products remain attached to the head in a "cocked" position.
  • When the troponin-tropomyosin complex binds with calcium ions, active sites on the actin filament are uncovered and the myosin heads then bind with these sites. 
  • The bond between the head of the cross-bridge and the active site of the actin causes a conformational change in the head and the power stroke occurs. The energy to the power stroke is derived from the energy which was stored like a cocked spring due to the cleavage of ATP in step 1.
  • Once the head of the cross-bridge tilts, the ADP and phosphate ions that were previously attached to the head are released and a new ATP molecule binds in that place, and the myosin head is "re-cocked".
  • The binding of the new ATP molecule causes detachment of the head of the myosin from the actin. This cycle is then repeated.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a diabetic foot. The plan is to amputate the foot at the level of A-B as shown below. What is the amputation at this level called?
questions.solution:
This level of amputation is called Syme's amputation.

Amputation at the level distal tibia and fibula 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of the ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. It is the most satisfactory functional level in the lower extremity when the outcome is good. The most common causes of an unsatisfactory Syme stump are posterior migration of the heel pad and skin slough resulting from overly vigorous trimming of “dog ears” or a compromised posterior tibial artery. The chief objection to this amputation is cosmetic.

Sarmiento modification of Syme technique is transection of the tibia and fibula approximately 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of the medial and lateral malleoli.

Related Pearl: List of Names of Amputations and Their Levels

TYPE 

LEVEL OF AMPUTATION 

Lisfranc

Tarsometatarsal joint 

Chopart 

Transverse tarsal joints (articulation of calcaneus with cuboid and talus with navicular)

Pirogoff

Calcaneum is rotated forward to be fused with tibia after vertical section through its middle 

Syme 

Distal tibia & fibula 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. Involves removal of both medial and lateral malleoli.

Boyd 

Talectomy, forward shift of the calcaneus and calcaneo-tibial arthrodesis 

Sarmiento 

Distal tibia and fibula: 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of medial and lateral malleoli

questions.text: A young girl was rushed to the emergency room in a delirious state. Her parents reported her to have consumed a wild fruit as shown below while on a camping trip. On examination, photophobia, staggering gait, flushing, and dry mucous membranes are noticed. The pupils are bilaterally dilated. Which of the following plant poisons she may have consumed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing cherry-like fruit is suggestive that the plant poison the patient may have consumed is Atropa belladonna. 

Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

Clinical manifestations of Atropa belladonna poisoning include: 

  • Fever, flushing, rash
  • Neurological symptoms - delirium, slurred speech, headache, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations, convulsions and coma
  • Eye symptoms - photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light
  • Cardiovascular symptoms - arrhythmia, tachycardia, hypertension
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms - severely dry mouth and throat, decreased bowel sounds, constipation, ileus
  • Renal symptoms - urinary retention

Anticholinergic symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis and urinary retention. 

Treatment - Conservative management with gastric lavage with activated charcoal. Benzodiazepines are used to control agitation and delirium. Physostigmine is a specific antidote, that should be given in cases of tachycardia, coma and respiratory arrest.

 

Other options - 

Option A - Datura poisoning also presents with similar symptoms, but the image given is not of datura stramonium.

Option B - Nicotiana tabacum is a cardiac poison, all parts of the plant are poisonous except the ripe seeds. Acute poisoning results in burning sensation, abdominal pain, hypersalivation, tachycardia, hypotension, and respiratory depression.

Option C - Ricinus poisoning leads to symptoms such as the burning of oral mucosa, salivation, nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhoea. It may also cause drowsiness, convulsions, delirium, and death. The entire plant is poisonous, but seeds are the most toxic and toxic principle is toxalbumin ricin which acts by blocking protein synthesis.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

Related Pearl: Certain specific clinical features diagnostic of poisons and poisoning

Clinical features Possible causes
Pupillary constriction (Miosis) Barbiturates, caffeine, carbamates, carbolic acid (phenol), clonidine, methyl dopa, nicotine, opiates, organophosphates, parasympathomimetics.
Pupillary dilatation (Mydriasis) Alcohol (constricted in coma), amphetamines, antihistamines, benzodiazepines, carbon monoxide, cocaine, cyanide, datura (atropine), ephedrine
Hippus (alternate constriction and dilatation of pupils) Aconite, alcohol, barbiturates.
Nystagmus Alcohol, barbiturates, carbamazepine, phencyclidine, phenytoin
Pinpoint pupils, and reduced respiratory rate Opioids, cholinesterase inhibitors (organophosphorus or carbamate insecticides), clonidine, phenothiazines, Pontine hemorrhage
Cyanosis Any CNS depressant or agent causing methemoglobinemia
Needle tracks, pinpoint pupils, and reduced respiratory rate IV Opioids
Dilated pupils or mid-point pupils, and reduced respiratory rate Benzodiazepines
Dilated pupils, tachycardia
  • Tricyclic antidepressants – dry mouth, warm peripheries, may also be twitchy or have seizures
  • Amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine – may also be hallucinating or agitated
  • Anticholinergic drugs such as benzhexol, benztropine – may also have hyperreflexia and myoclonus
  • Antihistamines – may also be drowsy
Increased salivation Organophosphorus or carbamate insecticides

Hypothermia

 

 Lithium, tricyclic antidepressants, anticholinergics, antihistamines

Hyperthermia
  • Amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine (also hypertension, tachycardia, agitation, rhabdomyolysis)
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (also confusion, fluctuating consciousness, rigidity, tremor, autonomic instability, sweating, rhabdomyolysis)
  • Serotonin syndrome (also agitation, clonus, tremor, hyperreflexia, sweating, tachycardia)
  • Salicylates including aspirin (also tachycardia, metabolic acidosis, restlessness, hyperventilation)
Hypertension Amphetamine, ephedrine, cocaine, clonidine, MAO inhibitors, thyroid hormones
Hypotension Cyanide, alcohol, digitalis, carbon monoxide, narcotics, barbiturates
Abdominal cramps, diarrhea, tachycardia, restlessness, hallucinations Withdrawal from: Alcohol, benzodiazepines, opioids
Bradycardia Beta-blockers, calcium antagonists (not dihydropyridines), digoxin, opioids, organophosphorus insecticides, centrally acting alpha agonists, e.g. clonidine
Seizures Tricyclic antidepressants, theophylline, antihistamines, anticonvulsants, non-steroidal drugs, phenol, phenothiazines, isoniazid, cocaine, carbon monoxide, organophosphorus insecticides, strychnine

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease presented with a sudden onset of severe headache and vomiting. On examination, marked neck rigidity was noted. Cerebrospinal fluid tap reveals findings as shown in the image. Which among the following drugs is ideal for preventing delayed cerebral ischemia?
questions.solution:
Nimodipine is ideal to prevent delayed cerebral ischaemia in this patient.

The clinical vignette describing a patient with sudden onset headache with meningeal signs of neck rigidity and CSF fluid showing xanthochromia is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH). Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is commonly associated with intracranial aneurysms.

Nimodipine, which belongs to the dihydropyridine group of drugs, is an L-type calcium channel blocker recommended for all patients with aneurysmal SAH to prevent cerebral vasospasm and delayed cerebral ischemia.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage: 

Etiology - Traumatic or rupture of aneurysms

Clinical features - Thunderclap headache, photophobia, loss of consciousness, vomiting, neck pain, or stiffness

Diagnosis - Non-contrast CT head, lumbar puncture shows xanthochromia

Treatment - Blood pressure must be controlled and maintained at systolic blood pressure (SBP) <160 mmHg or mean arterial pressure (MAP) <110 mmHg.  Nimodipine 60 mg every four hours is administered to all patients with aneurysmal SAH starting within 48 hours of symptom onset. Nimodipine prevents cerebral vasospasm. Management of the aneurysm is done with surgical clipping or endovascular coiling.

Other options:

Option A: Tranexamic acid is an inhibitor of fibrinolysis used in the management of intraoperative bleeding, major head injury and trauma resuscitation.

Option B: Phenytoin is a sodium channel modulator used in the management of focal seizures and generalised tonic-clonic seizures.

Option C: Nifedipine also belongs to the dihydropyridine group of drugs which are calcium channel blockers and is used for management of vasospastic angina, preventing exertional angina, management of hypertension etc.

questions.text: A child is brought with complaints of bitemporal hemianopia, severe headaches associated with vomiting, growth failure, and delayed sexual maturation. CT scan showed the presence of a tumor with calcifications. T1 weighed MRI of the brain is done and is shown below. What is the embryonal basis for this tumor?
questions.solution:
The child has a craniopharyngioma derived from the Rathke pouch, which may persist in the roof of the nasopharynx as a pharyngeal hypophysis.

Rathke’s pouch appears as an evagination of the oral cavity at about 3 weeks of embryonic life. It grows dorsally towards the infundibulum and eventually loses its connection to the oral cavity by the end of the 8th week. The anterior wall cells multiply rapidly to form the anterior pituitary or adenohypophysis, and the posterior wall of the pouch forms pars intermedia. The anterior wall cells have a small extension that grows along the stalk of the infundibulum, forming pars tuberalis.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually present in the suprasellar or intrasellar regions. They arise near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to the mass effect. They can be clinically aggressive due to their tendency to recur. Adamantinomatous (children) and papillary (adults) are two variants of craniopharyngioma. 

Patients usually come to attention due to a headache and visual changes, including decreased acuity or visual field abnormalities (bitemporal hemianopia). These children also have endocrinologic abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction and growth hormone deficiency. They are minimally invasive, adhere to the adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf normal brain structures.

CT may show calcifications within the tumor. MRI shows the presence of solid tumors with cystic components. These tumors appear bright on T1.

They are treated by trans-sphenoidal or trans-cranial resection followed by adjuvant radiation therapy.

questions.text: The ophthalmological examination findings of a 40-year-old male patient who is on antiglaucoma treatment is as shown below. Which of the following drugs is likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
The ophthalmological examination shows a pearly white opacity of the lens indicative of cataract. Anticholinesterase agents like echothiophate and cholinergic agonists like pilocarpine are known to be associated with cataract formation.

Other options:

Options A: Specific side effects of apraclonidine are an allergy (conjunctival hyperemia), dry mouth, and sleepiness.

Options C: Specific side effects of brimonidine are an allergy (conjunctival hyperemia), dry mouth, sleepiness, and also causes respiratory depression in young children.

Option D: Specific side effects of timolol are exacerbation of respiratory problems like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, impotence.

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

Anti-glaucoma drug The adverse effects
Beta-blockers

Corneal hypoesthesia

Systemic side effects
Sympathomimetics

Lid retraction

CNS depression and apnea in infants and children (<2 years)
Prostaglandin analogs

Eyelash hypertrichosis

Macular edema

Iris pigmentation (Heterochromia iridis)

Peri-orbital fat depletion
Miotics

Retinal detachment

Cataract
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Systemic side effects

Corneal edema

questions.text:

  3. Defective DNA base excision repair (BER)
  4. Defective DNA mismatch repair (MMR)
  5. Defective nonhomologous end-joining repair (NHEJ)

 

  1. Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)
  2. MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP)
  3. Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)
  4. Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)
  5. Bloom syndrome (BS)
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient in the ICU is undergoing monitoring with the device below. The waveform obtained on its insertion is shown below and is marked with an arrow. Choose the correct statements about this procedure.
  1. The device shown in the image is placed in the right atrium 
  2. Central venous pressure can be obtained directly using this device
  3. Infection at the insertion site is an absolute contraindication to placement
  4. Both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias can occur during the procedure
  5. The cardiac index can be obtained directly using this device
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-Ganz catheter used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter. The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. The graph depicts the waveforms recorded by a Swan Ganz catheter while positioned in different parts of the heart. The arrow specifically points to the catheter being placed in the pulmonary artery with a mean pressure between 10-20 mm Hg. The correct options from those above are 2, 3 and 4. 

A Swan Ganz catheter or pulmonary artery catheter is used for the evaluation of a range of conditions.

The indications for their use are -

  • Unexplained volume status in shock
  • Severe cardiogenic shock 
  • Suspected or previously diagnosed pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Patients with severe underlying cardiopulmonary diseases such as congenital heart disease, valvular disease, or left-to-right shunts undergoing surgery

 The following direct measurements can be obtained from an accurately placed catheter-  

  • Central venous pressure (CVP)
  • Right-sided intracardiac pressures (right atrium and right ventricle)
  • Pulmonary artery pressure
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Mixed venous oxyhemoglobin saturation

Indirect measurements that can be obtained from the catheter are - 

  • Systemic vascular resistance
  • Pulmonary vascular resistance
  • Cardiac index
  • Stroke volume index
  • Left ventricular stroke work index
  • Right ventricular stroke work index
  • Oxygen delivery
  • Oxygen uptake

Contraindication to the insertion of this catheter are: 

Absolute - Infection at the insertion site, presence of a right ventricular assist device, insertion during cardiopulmonary bypass, and lack of consent

Relative - coagulopathy, electrolyte disturbances, acid-base disturbances, right or left bundle branch block 

 

Complications:

With insertion: Arrhythmias (both atrial and ventricular), misplacement, knotting, myocardial vessel or valve rupture.

With maintenance: Pulmonary valve perforation, pulmonary infarction, thromboembolism, infection, pseudoaneurysms, endocarditis

 

The images below show the position of the catheter and the waveforms recorded when the catheter is placed in different parts of the heart with the pressures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with difficulty swallowing, excessive tiredness, and loss of weight over the last few months. After further blood investigations and imaging, a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome was made. Which of the following findings is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
An esophageal web is likely to be seen in a patient with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome. It is typically seen in women over 40 years of age. It includes the following features:

  • Dysphagia 
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Glossitis
  • Angular stomatitis
  • Koilonychia
  • Achlorhydria

The esophageal webs refer to esophageal constrictions caused by an atrophic mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen formed due to subepithelial fibrosis. They are usually seen in the cervical esophagus near post cricoid region.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is a known risk factor for post-cricoid hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.  

Other options-

Option A:  Achalasia cardia is characterized by the absence of peristalsis in the body of the esophagus and high resting pressure in the lower esophagus sphincter (LES). The LES does not relax when the patient swallows. This leads to dysphagia more to liquids than solids and regurgitation of food at night. A barium swallow will reveal a dilated esophagus with narrowed rat tail lower end called bird beak appearance. The barium swallow findings are seen in the image below. 

Option B: Diffuse esophageal spasm is a motility disorder of the esophagus. It is seen as a corkscrew appearance on a barium swallow. Esophageal manometry will show normal relaxation of the sphincter on swallowing. A barium swallow image of diffuse esophageal spasm is shown below-

Option C: Esophageal leiomyoma is a common benign tumor of the esophagus. On a barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium. A barium study with the classic semilunar filling defect in esophageal leiomyoma is shown below-

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. The stool demonstrates occult blood. The small bowel is found to have a small infarcted area which is surgically removed. Histopathologic examination on the resected bowel reveals fibrinoid necrosis of an artery with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate containing neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells. In this patient, such fibrinoid necrosis can be seen in all of the following except _______
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). It characteristically spares the pulmonary circulation.

PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically involves the renal (most commonly involved) and visceral vessels. It has no association with ANCA, but about 30% of patients have chronic hepatitis-B.

The patient may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by gastrointestinal vessels' involvement.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes with cough, chest pain which increases on cough or deep inspiration, dyspnea and shortness of breath. He has had high-grade fever with chills for the last 4 days. On examination, his temp is 102 F, PR is 108 bpm and BP is 110/70 and RR is 23 cpm. You notice needle track marks on his left forearm.  Cardiac auscultation reveals a faint systolic murmur in the lower left sternal border which has not been recorded before. Which of the following images describes the vegetations associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's history and clinical findings are suggestive of infective endocarditis. Option B shows the vegetations in infective endocarditis.

A vegetation in infective endocarditis is a mass of platelets, fibrin, microorganisms, and scant inflammatory cells. Infection most commonly involves heart valves but may also occur on the low-pressure side of a ventricular septal defect, on mural endocardium damaged by aberrant jets of blood or foreign bodies, or on intracardiac devices themselves.

On gross examination, the vegetations in infective endocarditis appear as large irregular masses on the valve cusps that extend into the chordae tendinae. Valvular involvement and ruptured chordae tendinae result in new regurgitant murmurs in acute endocarditis.

In this patient with high-grade fever, dyspnea and shortness of breath, a new onset cardiac murmur is suggestive of valvular pathology, most likely infective endocarditis. In patients with a history of IV drug abuse (needle track marks on left forearm), tricuspid valve is the most commonly involved valve. Staphylococcus aureus (often MRSA) is the most commonly implicated pathogen.

Tricuspid valve infective endocarditis presents with fever. However the murmur is faint or absent in tricuspid valve endocarditis. Peripheral manifestations are also rare. Septic pulmonary emboli, which are common with tricuspid endocarditis, cause cough, pleuritic chest pain, nodular pulmonary infiltrates, and occasionally empyema or pyopneumothorax.

The different types of vegetations seen in other valvular conditions is shown below.

questions.text: The given instrument is used to test _________
questions.solution:
The given instrument is synoptophore and it is used to test binocular single vision.

Binocular single vision is the state of simultaneous vision, which is achieved by the coordinated use of both eyes so that separate and slightly dissimilar images arising in each eye are appreciated as a single image by the process of fusion.

The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the presence of a manifest squint and is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 years), who generally find the test process enjoyable.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty in breathing. Chest X-ray shows multiple linear opacities in bilateral lower lungs. Which of the following will be seen in this patient's pulmonary function tests?
  1. Increased Residual Volume
  2. Decreased DLCO
  3. FEV1/FVC > 0.7
  4. Increased FEV1
  5. Normal total lung capacity
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 3 are correct in this case scenario.

The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in a ship repair industry with linear opacities on chest X-ray is Asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern.

Asbestosis results in diffuse interstitial fibrosis leading to restrictive lung disease. On pulmonary function testing, there is

  • Decreased total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity (VC), and residual volume (RV) due to diffuse fibrosis.
  • In restrictive diseases, both FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) are reduced but FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or even increased as FVC is reduced to a greater degree due to decreased compliance.
  • An FEV1/FVC ratio > 0.7 signifies restrictive lung disorder, whereas <0.7 is seen in obstructive diseases.
  • Damage to the pulmonary capillaries due to fibrosis causes a decrease in diffusing capacity, resulting in reduced DLco.
  • Flow volume loop in restrictive diseases shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

 

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman  presents to the CHC with complaints of vaginal discharge for 1 month. She also complains of a burning sensation in her vaginal area and urinary frequency for the past 5 days. There is no history of fever. Vitals are within normal limits and physical examination reveals a greenish frothy vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, you are able to see the below finding. Which of the following kits would you prescribe this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing strawberry cervix are suggestive of Trichomoniasis. The green kit containing Tablet Secnidazole 2 gm, to be taken orally as a single dose is recommended in its treatment.

Trichomoniasis is the infection of the female genital tract with the Trichomonas vaginalis protozoan. It characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. The vagina looks red and inflamed like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

Management: The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose or Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose
  • The alternative regimen includes Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days
  • Metronidazole gel does not reach therapeutic levels in the urethra and perivaginal glands. It is not recommended as it is less efficacious than oral metronidazole.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old lady who recently went in for an IUCD contraception has increasing pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before her menses begin. The pain is relieved once the menses starts. What is the clinical diagnosis in this case?

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
Pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before menses are suggestive of congestive dysmenorrhea.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain that occurs during menstruation.

It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea is a type of dysmenorrhoea that is not associated with any pelvic pathology. It affects women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles.
  • Secondary (Acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and endometriosis. 

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most common and is characterized by cramping pain on the first and second days of menstruation. 
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea presents as worsening pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain, a few days before the onset of menses followed by relief of the symptoms. This is seen in PID, IUCD users, varicosities of pelvic veins, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is rare and is characterized by crampy pain that occurs with the passage of the endometrium as a cast at the time of menstruation.

Primary dysmenorrhea can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), combined oral contraceptive pills, and progestin-only pills. GnRH agonists and androgens are also useful. Surgical management includes hysterectomy and is indicated if not responding to medical management. In secondary dysmenorrhea, treating the cause is needed.

Fibromyalgia is a disorder with diffuse musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It is associated with irritable bowel syndrome, anxiety, and depression. There is no cure for fibromyalgia as of now, although the symptoms can be controlled by medications. Researchers believe that fibromyalgia amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

questions.text: Thickening of stratum spinosum is seen in?
questions.solution:
Thickening of stratum spinosum is seen in acanthosis.

Acanthosis is a term that describes an increase in the number of cells in the Malpighian or prickle cell layer of the epidermis. Acanthosis is observed in:

  • Viral warts
  • Chronic eczema
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus

Other options: 

Option A: Acantholysis refers to the loss of connections between keratinocytes, due to the breakdown of intercellular bridges formed by desmosomes. It is seen in Pemphigus and its variants, Darier disease, etc. The site of the acantholysis in Pemphigus foliaceus and Pemphigus erythematosus, is in the upper part of the epidermis, whereas in Pemphigus vulgaris, it is at a lower level in the epidermis.

Option C: Hyperkeratosis is a thickening of the stratum corneum due to the presence of abnormal quantities of keratin. It can be seen in keratodermas.

Option D: A hypertrophic scar is an excessive connective tissue response to injury. There is epidermal thickening with increased fibroblasts and mast cells.
